abstract: Some employers are adopting unlimited vacation policies, and employees have mixed reactions.
snippet: Some employers are adopting unlimited vacation policies, and employees have mixed reactions.
lead_paragraph: One of the trendy perks at progressive companies is unlimited vacation time. The pitch is that responsible adults are capable of managing their own time so why not allow them to decide which hours and days to work as long as as the work gets done. It’s yet one more way that the employed are starting to resemble the self-employed. But as any entrepreneur knows, having the ability to take off as much time as you want doesn’t necessarily mean that you’ll use it. Often, the self-employed are so driven and consumed by work that vacations are all but squeezed out. I was about to write on this subject when I noticed that The Boston Globe Magazine had just written about the issue, touching on all the major points I would have made.

headline.main: Does Unlimited Vacation Equal No Vacation?

abstract: The Clorox Company reported a fourth-quarter profit that fell less than analysts estimated as the maker of Glad trash bags and its namesake bleach increased prices and sold more of its products. Clorox’s environmentally friendly cleaners and Burt’s Bees products led sales growth in the quarter, suggesting the company would continue to expand amid record high prices for oil, corn and soybeans. Net income declined to $158 million, or $1.13 a share, for the quarter that ended June 30, from $164 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier. Excluding reorganization and other costs, Clorox earned $1.18 a share. The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed was $1.10. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
lead_paragraph: The Clorox Company reported a fourth-quarter profit that fell less than analysts estimated as the maker of Glad trash bags and its namesake bleach increased prices and sold more of its products. Clorox’s environmentally friendly cleaners and Burt’s Bees products led sales growth in the quarter, suggesting the company would continue to expand amid record high prices for oil, corn and soybeans. Net income declined to $158 million, or $1.13 a share, for the quarter that ended June 30, from $164 million, or $1.07 a share, a year earlier. Excluding reorganization and other costs, Clorox earned $1.18 a share. The average estimate of 11 analysts surveyed was $1.10. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: Carl Icahn has lost a lot of money in WCI Communities, the homebuilder based in Florida, but at least he can be grateful that the board said no to his offer to buy the whole company. It was just last year, in March 2007, when Mr. Icahn offered $22 a share for the company. The board found that offer inadequate, and Mr. Icahn started a proxy fight for board representation. He won, and became chairman, but never completed a takeover. Bloomberg reports his companies and funds paid $112.6 million, or $18.46 a share, for a 16 percent stake.

lead_paragraph: Hearings in a closely watched, $22 billion lawsuit against the Bank of New York in a Russian court were postponed until October after one of the witnesses, Robert Blakey, an expert on United States antiracketeering law, fell ill. Russian authorities are suing the bank, claiming it made improper wire transfers out of Russia in the late 1990s, at a time when capital flight helped deflate the Russian economy. abstract: Returning from vacation, I arrived home to find at my doorstop the latest issue of Portfolio, the not-quite-new Conde Nast business magazine, whose media critic is one Howell Raines, the former executive editor of The New York Times who left a couple of years before I got here. Anyway, I just read, somewhat dumbfounded, his latest column. It’s about how all of us in business journalism are being sandbagged by those awful people running Exxon Mobil and the other major oil companies, who are busy gouging us while tossing the press their “malarkey” about supply and demand being behind the rise in oil prices. Raines, apparently, is among the legions who believe it’s all a big plot by Big Oil, which could bring down the price with a snap of its powerful finger.
lead_paragraph: Returning from vacation, I arrived home to find at my doorstop the latest issue of Portfolio, the not-quite-new Conde Nast business magazine, whose media critic is one Howell Raines, the former executive editor of The New York Times who left a couple of years before I got here. Anyway, I just read, somewhat dumbfounded, his latest column. It’s about how all of us in business journalism are being sandbagged by those awful people running Exxon Mobil and the other major oil companies, who are busy gouging us while tossing the press their “malarkey” about supply and demand being behind the rise in oil prices. Raines, apparently, is among the legions who believe it’s all a big plot by Big Oil, which could bring down the price with a snap of its powerful finger.

headline.main: Howell Raines, Conspiracy Theorist

abstract: Some additional thoughts for those seeking encore careers.

lead_paragraph: Whenever I write about baby boomers reinventing themselves and forging encore careers, I am bombarded by e-mails from readers. They say that they, too, want to reinvent and would relish the chance to do work with social utility but are deterred or discouraged by the need to earn a living. That is why I continue to applaud the work of organizations like Civic Ventures and other resources (read through the comments to this post for many suggestions), which are helping people find ways to create these encore careers.

abstract: Over the last few days, General Motors has made two related announcements. First, the company disclosed that it had lost a stunning $15.5 billion in the second quarter. And then, G.M. followed up that bad news by letting it be known that the company’s board remained steadfast in its support for the chief executive Rick Wagoner. “Rick has the unified support of the entire board to a person,” the company’s lead outside director, George M.C. Fisher, told Bill Vlasic of The Times in an interview Wednesday morning. “We are absolutely convinced we have the right team under Rick Wagoner’s leadership to get us through these difficult times and to a brighter future.”
lead_paragraph: Over the last few days, General Motors has made two related announcements. First, the company disclosed that it had lost a stunning $15.5 billion in the second quarter. And then, G.M. followed up that bad news by letting it be known that the company’s board remained steadfast in its support for the chief executive Rick Wagoner. “Rick has the unified support of the entire board to a person,” the company’s lead outside director, George M.C. Fisher, told Bill Vlasic of The Times in an interview Wednesday morning. “We are absolutely convinced we have the right team under Rick Wagoner’s leadership to get us through these difficult times and to a brighter future.”

abstract: You can conserve paper by saving receipts from Web purchases as PDF files instead of printing them.
snippet: You can conserve paper by saving receipts from Web purchases as PDF files instead of printing them.
lead_paragraph: You can conserve paper by saving receipts from Web purchases as PDF files instead of printing them. A free program, CutePDF, converts an onscreen Web receipt to a PDF file by just using the Print command and choosing “CutePDF Writer” as the printer. The program and a required helper script are both available at www.cutepdf.com and there are other similar programs around the Web; Microsoft has a free PDF add-on for Office 2007 at snipurl.com/3aqxp. In the Mac OS X Print dialog box, click the PDF button to see your PDF options  including a “Save PDF File to Web Receipts Folder” command.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Conserving Paper

abstract: Overstock.com, as readers of this blog know, likes to sue people whom it deems responsible for the “naked short selling” that it blames for driving down its share price. It has sued more-or-less every big brokerage firm for facilitating such sales. It has also sued Gradient Analytics, a research firm that wrote negatively about Overstock, and Rocker Partners, a hedge fund that sold its stock short. (There is no claim that Rocker was a naked short seller, just an ordinary one that borrowed shares and sold them.)

lead_paragraph: The British bank Barclays reported first-half profit that fell less than analysts had estimated, even after increasing write-downs of bad debts. Net income declined 34 percent, to £1.72 billion ($3.4 billion), or 26.2 pence a share, in the first six months of the year. Barclays marked down £2.8 billion of credit-related assets, more than analysts had predicted, and still exceeded their average profit estimate of £1.5 billion. Barclays Capital, the investment bank, had pretax profit of £524 million, down 69 percent from the year-ago first half.

headline.main: Britain: Barclays Profit Tops Forecasts
headline.print_headline: BRITAIN: BARCLAYS PROFIT TOPS FORECASTS

lead_paragraph: Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes, the Brazilian airline, suspended dividend payments for the rest of the year and reduced growth forecasts, sending its shares down sharply. The carrier said it would cancel leases on seven planes and offer 5 percent fewer seats in 2008 than previously planned. It was the second reduction in capacity this year. Gol, based in São Paulo, is seeking to conserve cash after back-to-back quarterly losses.

abstract: Canada’s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive.
snippet: Canada’s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s highest court agreed to hear an appeal by former employees of Wal-Mart Stores who say the company closed a store in Quebec because of a union drive. In 2004, employees at Wal-Mart’s store in Jonquière became the company’s first North American personnel organized by the United Food and Commercial Workers. Wal-Mart argued that the store, about 290 miles north of Montreal, was unprofitable and that its 2005 closing was unrelated to the union. Quebec’s provincial labor commission dismissed the workers’ complaint that they were fired for their union activities, saying Wal-Mart had showed adequate cause for its decision to close the store.

headline.main: Canada: Appeal of a Wal-Mart Closing
headline.print_headline: CANADA: APPEAL OF A WAL-MART CLOSING

abstract: My column this Saturday tackles a hard-to-answer question: how much good can a company with a conscience really do? In the case at hand, the company is De Beers, which for nearly a century was an out-and-out monopolist that worked diligently (and successfully) to control the world’s supply of diamonds — and that, in the last decade, has had the kind of conversion experience you don’t often see in large corporations. While still a big, dominant player (it sells 40 percent of the world’s rough stones today), it competes quite happily in a market economy, where the goal is to expand the demand, not control supply. I did not know any of this until I started in on this column — it was quite the revelation to realize that De Beers had become a more “normal” company.
lead_paragraph: My column this Saturday tackles a hard-to-answer question: how much good can a company with a conscience really do? While still a big, dominant player (it sells 40 percent of the world’s rough stones today), it competes quite happily in a market economy, where the goal is to expand the demand, not control supply. abstract: Delphi, the bankrupt former auto parts unit of General Motors, said that its net loss narrowed to $551 million in the second quarter from a year earlier, when it had costs from lawsuits and a plant closing.
snippet: Delphi, the bankrupt former auto parts unit of General Motors, said that its net loss narrowed to $551 million in the second quarter from a year earlier, when it had costs from lawsuits and a plant closing.
lead_paragraph: Delphi, the bankrupt former auto parts unit of General Motors, said that its net loss narrowed to $551 million in the second quarter from a year earlier, when it had costs from lawsuits and a plant closing. The net loss was 98 cents a share, compared with $821 million, or $1.46 a share, a year earlier, the company, based in Troy, Mich., said. Sales fell 13 percent, to $5.2 billion. Separately, the company said that it was negotiating with G.M. on changes to its restructuring plan, including the transfer of some Delphi “postretirement benefit obligations” to the automaker. G.M., which spun off Delphi in 1999, is already providing $650 million to Delphi, and it said in a separate filing that it might lend the former unit an additional $300 million. It also said that it was possible that Delphi would never emerge from bankruptcy.

headline.main: Delphi Reports a Narrower Loss
headline.print_headline: Delphi Reports a Narrower Loss

abstract: Telecom Italia said second-quarter profit slid 12 percent on price cuts enforced by regulators and slower mobile phone growth in Italy and Brazil.
snippet: Telecom Italia said second-quarter profit slid 12 percent on price cuts enforced by regulators and slower mobile phone growth in Italy and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Telecom Italia, Italy’s biggest phone company, said second-quarter profit slid 12 percent on price cuts enforced by regulators and slower mobile phone growth in Italy and Brazil. Net income fell to 639 million euros ($961 million) from 725 million euros a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales dropped 4.1 percent, to 7.54 billion euros. The company cut its full-year revenue forecast because of reduced outlooks in Brazil and Germany, where competition has stiffened.

headline.main: Price Cuts Push Profit Down at Telecom Italia

abstract: So writes Jing Ulrich, who follows the Chinese equity market out of JP Morgan’s Hong Kong office, in her latest note to clients. (For the record: A shares are stocks of Chinese companies listed on the Shanghai exchange; H shares are Chinese stocks traded on the Hong Kong exchange.) Since last year, Ms. Ulrich has been following the steep decline of the Shanghai A shares — and the many steps the government has taken to stabilize the market. None have worked, and it is highly unlike that these two new proposals — reforming the stamp duty and establishing a “stabilizing fund” to help prop up the market — will work either.
lead_paragraph: So writes Jing Ulrich, who follows the Chinese equity market out of JP Morgan’s Hong Kong office, in her latest note to clients. (For the record: A shares are stocks of Chinese companies listed on the Shanghai exchange; H shares are Chinese stocks traded on the Hong Kong exchange.) Since last year, Ms. Ulrich has been following the steep decline of the Shanghai A shares — and the many steps the government has taken to stabilize the market. None have worked, and it is highly unlike that these two new proposals — reforming the stamp duty and establishing a “stabilizing fund” to help prop up the market — will work either.

headline.main: Why Won’t China Trust Mr. Market?

abstract: Singapore Telecommunications, Southeast Asia’s largest phone company, reported a profit that fell more than analysts had estimated.
snippet: Singapore Telecommunications, Southeast Asia’s largest phone company, reported a profit that fell more than analysts had estimated.
lead_paragraph: Singapore Telecommunications, Southeast Asia’s largest phone company, reported a profit that fell more than analysts estimated and said strength in the local currency would erode overseas earnings this year. Net income fell 5.3 percent, to 878.1 million Singapore dollars ($623 million) in the three months to June 30, the company said. Sales rose 5.9 percent, to 3.78 billion Singapore dollars. Profit from mobile affiliates, including those in Indonesia and the Philippines, declined 6.2 percent, the first decline in 13 quarters.

headline.main: Singapore: Currency Rate Hurts Telecom Profit
headline.print_headline: SINGAPORE: CURRENCY RATE HURTS TELECOM PROFIT

abstract: The Hyundai Steel Company said second-quarter profit surged 70 percent with higher prices and increased exports.
snippet: The Hyundai Steel Company said second-quarter profit surged 70 percent with higher prices and increased exports.
lead_paragraph: The Hyundai Steel Company, the South Korean steel maker, said second-quarter profit surged 70 percent as higher prices and increased exports helped the company weather rising material costs. Net income rose to 325.5 billion won ($315 million), from 191.2 billion won a year earlier, the company said. Sales climbed 48 percent to 2.95 trillion won. Hyundai, which is based in Inchon, lifted exports to the Middle East, Europe and Southeast Asia, it said. It raised prices 76 percent this year to cope with the higher costs of materials like scrap.

headline.main: South Korea: Hyundai Steel’s Profit Rises
headline.print_headline: SOUTH KOREA: HYUNDAI STEEL’S PROFIT RISES

snippet: Responding to Web critics, Google has modified its Reader service to allow users to choose the people who have access to their list of favorite blog items.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Google caused a bit of a furor when it expanded the sharing capabilities of Google Reader, the company’s service for viewing blogs. The main complaint was that Google assumed that anyone you had exchanged messages with using Google Talk was your friend. If those people were Google Reader users, they would be able to see any item you marked as “shared.”

headline.main: Google Now Allows You to Pick Your Friends in Reader

abstract: Scan in copies of your passport, driver’s license, visas, prescriptions, medical records and customer-service phone numbers for your bank and stores those files on a U.S.B. drive.
snippet: Scan in copies of your passport, driver’s license, visas, prescriptions, medical records and customer-service phone numbers for your bank and stores those files on a U.S.B. drive.
lead_paragraph: If you have a scanner, you can easily keep digital copies of all your important documents when traveling. Just scan in copies of your passport, driver’s license, visas, prescriptions, medical records and customer-service phone numbers for your bank and credit card companies. Store the files on a U.S.B. drive to keep your information right in your pocket if you lose the paper versions on your travels. Most computers in hotels and Internet cafes have a U.S.B. port if you need the information. Storing the digital data on a secure, password-protected online storage site is another option, in case you lose the U.S.B. drive too.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Taking Important Documents on the Road

abstract: Why it is a good idea to find people whose careers mirror yours.
snippet: Why it is a good idea to find people whose careers mirror yours.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago Greg Roth, a colleague of mine at The Times, spoke of someone as having a “mirror career” to his. He and this other person had similar educational backgrounds, had worked for some of the same companies, and had even worked overseas in the same country. Though I’d never heard it before, I instantly knew what he meant and realized that I had been collecting a few “mirrors” in my own professional circle. I also started thinking about why it is smart to stay in touch with people whose careers mirror elements of yours.

headline.main: When Your Career Has a Mirror Image

abstract: CBS ranked runner up in the ratings for the fifth consecutive night on Thursday, trailing far behind NBC’s ongoing coverage of the Olympics but earning modest audiences for “Big Brother” and “Flashpoint.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two CBS series delivered 6.7 million and 6.3 million viewers, respectively, at 8 and 10 p.m. In between, CBS broadcast a rerun of “CSI” at 9 p.m. (6.1 million). Meanwhile, the Summer Games attracted an average of 28 million viewers for NBC during prime time, slightly more than Wednesday night’s final tally of 27.7 million from 8 to 11:26 p.m. The audience peaked on Thursday during the 10 p.m. time slot, during which the network captured Michael Phelps winning his sixth Beijing gold medal and the 12th of his career. Nearly 35 million viewers were tuned in to NBC that hour. Fox third for the night with ABC close behind in fourth. Both networks averaged well under 4 million viewers. Fox’s pre-season football coverage was interrupted for an hour due to severe weather, making precise audience figures unavailable until final ratings are released later today. ABC broadcast repeats of “Ugly Betty” at 8 p.m. (3.1 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” at 9 p.m. (3.7 million) and “Private Practice” at 10 p.m. (2.7 million).

abstract: The Fair Game column last Sunday, about Merrill Lynch’s agreement to unwind credit insurance it bought from a bond insurer, misidentified the name of that insurer at the time it was announced. XL was a subsidiary of it, not its parent. (After the announcement, XL became Syncora Guarantee and Security Capital Assurance became Syncora Holdings.).

lead_paragraph: If we have learned anything from this unrelenting credit mess, The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson writes in her weekly column, it is that greater disclosure is needed if investors are to regain their trust in the financial system. abstract: Several hours ago, Apple shipped its second software update for the new iPhone 3G. Software version 2.02 “fixes bugs,” according to the documentation accompanying the software patch. lead_paragraph: The brand-new radio chip in the Apple iPhone 3G has been causing the company a bit of indigestion in recent weeks as customers complain about dropped phone calls and intermittent connections to the highly touted 3G network. (My own solution was to just switch off the 3G and drop down to AT&T’s slower EDGE network. It might have been my imagination, but it appeared that that the result was better power efficiency, and to my definitely random sample, a more reliable network.)

headline.main: Has the iPhone 3G Been Fixed?

abstract: “I knew this day would come,” Bill Ford Jr., told Maria Bartiromo in the latest issue of Business Week. “I’ve been an environmentalist my whole life, and I’ve fought a lot of battles during 30 years at Ford.” He continued: “I was viewed as a bit of a Bolshevik throughout my whole career because I knew this day was coming. So we built the Rouge Plant, which was the greenest plant on the planet and….we also launched the first American hybrid, the Escape. But gasoline prices were cheap, and customers were buying many more of our big F-150s than they were of our Escape hybrids.”

lead_paragraph: For decades, it has been practically an unwritten rule of office building design that a high-end building should have lushly landscaped lobbies or atriums. The forest’s worth of magnolia, pear and eucalyptus placed inside the Ford Foundation building in 1967 perhaps kicked off the trend, which culminated in the late 1980s when the World Financial Center decorated its Winter Garden with rows of soaring palms.

abstract: Tsingtao Brewery, China’s largest beer company by sales, said first-half profit rose 32 percent after publicity from sponsoring the Beijing Olympics increased demand.
snippet: Tsingtao Brewery, China’s largest beer company by sales, said first-half profit rose 32 percent after publicity from sponsoring the Beijing Olympics increased demand.
lead_paragraph: Tsingtao Brewery, China’s largest beer company by sales, said first-half profit rose 32 percent after publicity from sponsoring the Beijing Olympics increased demand. Net income climbed to 381.1 million yuan ($56 million), or 0.29 yuan a share, from 287.9 million yuan or 0.22 yuan, the company said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Sales rose 16 percent, to 7.9 billion yuan, from 6.83 billion yuan. Tsingtao, based in the eastern Chinese city of Qingdao, is hoping to use publicity from the sponsorship to increase full-year beer volume growth. Rising costs for electricity and raw materials are making production more expensive at Chinese brewers. Tsingtao Brewery, 27 percent owned by Anheuser-Busch, is aiming for a year-over-year increase in sales volume of 13 percent in 2008, after growing 11 percent in 2007.

headline.main: China: Olympics Help Tsingtao Sales
headline.print_headline: CHINA: OLYMPICS HELP TSINGTAO SALES

abstract: De Beers, the world’s largest producer of rough diamonds, said prices had increased an average of 16 percent since the beginning of the year.

lead_paragraph: De Beers, the world’s largest producer of rough diamonds, said prices had increased an average of 16 percent since the beginning of the year. The company’s Diamond Trading Company arm, which handles about 40 percent of the world’s supply of diamonds by value, said that the strongest cumulative price increases had been in rough stones that produce diamonds greater than one carat when polished. The company provides price adjustment information three times a year, ahead of its annual results and in advance of trade shows in Las Vegas and Hong Kong.

headline.main: South Africa: Diamond Prices Up 16%

lead_paragraph: KAESONG, North Korea  The Kaesong Industrial Park is worlds away from the North Korean city on whose outskirts it sits. While the South Korean-run industrial park has modern factories and motorists in sport utility vehicles, the city of Kaesong is straight out of the cold war. Long stretches of joyless gray apartment blocks loom above empty boulevards, and loud red signs proclaim the victory of the workers’ party.

abstract: Queensland Gas, one of the companies proposing a liquefied natural gas project in northeast Australia, has agreed to buy Sunshine Gas Ltd. for at least 837 million Australian dollars ($730 million).
snippet: Queensland Gas, one of the companies proposing a liquefied natural gas project in northeast Australia, has agreed to buy Sunshine Gas Ltd. for at least 837 million Australian dollars ($730 million).
lead_paragraph: Queensland Gas, one of the companies proposing a liquefied natural gas project in northeast Australia, has agreed to buy Sunshine Gas Ltd. for at least 837 million Australian dollars ($730 million), increasing its reserves by almost a quarter. The offer values the company, which extracts gas from coal seam reserves, at 2.70 or 2.88 Australian dollars a share, depending on whether shareholders accept all stock or a mix of cash and stock, Queensland Gas said. That is at least 23 percent higher than Tuesday’s closing share price for Sunshine Gas, based in Brisbane. Queensland Gas, also based in Brisbane, said it would use Sunshine’s reserves primarily to meet rising local demand, as well as to bolster its liquefied natural gas project, to be built in Gladstone, on the Queensland coast. That export facility will have estimated cost of 8 billion Australian dollars.

headline.main: Australia: Acquisition for Gas Company
headline.print_headline: AUSTRALIA: ACQUISITION FOR GAS COMPANY

abstract: Retail sales in Canada rose for a fourth consecutive month in June, led by higher gasoline prices and clothing purchases.
snippet: Retail sales in Canada rose for a fourth consecutive month in June, led by higher gasoline prices and clothing purchases.
lead_paragraph: Retail sales in Canada rose for a fourth consecutive month in June, led by higher gasoline prices and clothing purchases. Sales rose 0.5 percent to 36 billion Canadian dollars ($33.9 billion), Statistics Canada said, matching economists’ predictions after a revised 0.3 percent gain the month before. Sales rose in six of eight major categories the agency tracks, including gains of 2.5 percent at clothing stores and 1.3 percent for food and beverages. Higher gasoline prices pushed sales at filling stations up 4.2 percent. Excluding such fluctuations, retail sales would have dipped 0.4 percent. Gasoline pump prices rose 5.1 percent.

headline.main: Canada: Retail Sales Rise
headline.print_headline: CANADA: RETAIL SALES RISE

abstract: The unemployment rate in Russia fell in July to 5.3 percent, a lower rate than expected by economists.
snippet: The unemployment rate in Russia fell in July to 5.3 percent, a lower rate than expected by economists.
lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate in Russia fell in July to 5.3 percent, a lower rate than expected by economists. The rate dropped from 6.2 percent the month before, the Federal Statistics Service said. The median forecast of 15 economists surveyed by Bloomberg was 6.1 percent. The jobless rate in Russia, the world’s largest energy exporter, has declined from a high of 12.4 percent in 1999. The average monthly wage increased at an annual rate of 11.6 percent in July to 17,538 rubles ($718), the report said.

headline.main: Russia: Jobless Rate Falls

abstract: Eugene Upshaw, the 63-year-old head of the National Football League Players Association, died on Thursday morning of pancreatic cancer, and the football establishment spent the rest of the day singing his praises. “Gene Upshaw did everything with grace and dignity,” the NFL commissioner Roger Goodel said. Mr. Goodell’s predecessor, Paul Tagliabue, pointed to Mr. Upshaw’s “positive impact on the structure and competitiveness of the entire league.” Adam Schefter, an analyst with the NFL Network, called him “one of the most influential figures that has ever been involved in the sport of football.” Newsday’s football writer Bob Glauber: “There’s no question in my mind that his legacy will, in hindsight, be perceived as not good, but great.” And on, and on.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Upshaw, the 63-year-old head of the National Football League Players Association, died on Thursday morning of pancreatic cancer, and the football establishment spent the rest of the day singing his praises. “Gene Upshaw did everything with grace and dignity,” the NFL commissioner Roger Goodel said. abstract: My column this Saturday is a mini-history of the sins of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two entities that are supposed to help the country in times of financial duress, not add to its problems, as they have done. What got me going was an article I saw in The Boston Globe (which is owned by The New York Times Company), in which Freddie Mac’s chief executive, Richard Syron, made the absurd claim that the company’s troubles stemmed from his insistence that it reorient itself towards its mission of making affordable housing available to Americans. This — to put it nicely — is a crock, as I try to point out in the column.
lead_paragraph: My column this Saturday is a mini-history of the sins of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two entities that are supposed to help the country in times of financial duress, not add to its problems, as they have done. lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  With the decline in oil prices, inflationary pressures are easing for the moment. The Federal Reserve’s policy makers all acknowledge as much. But that has not halted their debate over whether to raise interest rates now to avoid higher inflation in the future.

headline.main: At the Fed, a Debate Over Countering Inflation Grows Louder
headline.print_headline: At the Fed, a Debate Over Countering Inflation Grows Louder

abstract: J.J. Abrams, the creator of “Lost,” is the producer of “Fringe,” a new sci-fi drama on Fox.
snippet: J.J. Abrams, the creator of “Lost,” is the producer of “Fringe,” a new sci-fi drama on Fox.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s New York Times, Dave Itzkoff profiles J.J. Abrams, the creator of “Lost,” who “practically invented” a TV storytelling style that “demands total commitment from audience members, requiring that they keep up not only with complicated single-episode plotlines (can a time-traveling castaway alter past events to help himself in the present?) but also with fiendishly intricate narratives (how did the Oceanic Six get off their mysterious island, and how might they get back?) that can take an entire season — or seasons, plural — to play out.”

headline.main: J.J. Abrams and the Art of the Narrative

abstract: I’ve been saying for weeks now — well, two weeks, anyway — that putting so much of the Games on live television probably made the difference between a successful Olympics and an unsuccessful one, at least from NBC’s point of view. Live sports are simply more compelling than taped sports, as the ratings — and the NBC’s $100 million in Olympic profit — clearly proved. But given the 12-hour time difference between Beijing and the East Coast of the United States, I had assumed that the deal to move many key events to the morning so that we in the United States could see them live in the evening had been struck between the International Olympic Committee and NBC, which paid $894 million for the rights to the Beijing Games.

abstract: Chile’s economy expanded faster than expected in the second quarter, giving the central bank room to raise interest rates to stem inflation.
snippet: Chile’s economy expanded faster than expected in the second quarter, giving the central bank room to raise interest rates to stem inflation.
lead_paragraph: Chile’s economy expanded faster than expected in the second quarter, giving the central bank room to raise interest rates to stem inflation. Its gross domestic product grew 4.3 percent in the second quarter, up from a revised 3.3 percent in the first quarter, the central bank said. Growth exceeded the 3.96 percent expected by analysts. The faster-than-expected growth was driven by an 11 percent increase in demand, suggesting policy makers can raise interest rates further without bringing the economy to a standstill. The central bank has raised its overnight rate by 1.25 percentage points to a nine-year high of 7.75 percent this year to try to bring down the highest inflation rate since 1994.

headline.main: Chile: Economic Growth Tops Forecasts
headline.print_headline: CHILE: ECONOMIC GROWTH TOPS FORECASTS

lead_paragraph: Last week’s post about a virtual assistant, Emily Morgan, who had taken an entrepreneurial approach to her work, evoked some heated discussion in the comments about the nature of entrepreneurship. The comments touched on what motivates people to choose different types of work arrangements, particularly whether the trappings that tend to accompany employment, like health insurance and paid vacation time, are more valuable than those that flow to the self-employed — like the ability to choose which projects to work on, the flexibility to work how and where a person wants, and a general feeling of controlling one’s destiny.

snippet: Want to turn the Mac’s screensaver into a dynamic billboard for news headlines, favorite blog feeds or even Facebook notifications?
lead_paragraph: Want to turn the Mac’s screensaver into a dynamic billboard for news headlines, favorite blog feeds or even Facebook notifications? Go to the System Preferences area in Mac OS X 10.4 or 10.5 and click on the Desktop and Screen Saver icon. Click the Screen Saver tab, choose RSS Visualizer and click the Options button to select a news feed to display when the screen saver kicks on. Windows users can find a number of shareware programs around the Web that do the same thing, including NuParadigm’s free RSS Screensaver software at www.nuparadigm.com/Products/Toys/RssScreensaver.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Adding RSS Feeds to Your Screensaver

abstract: When last we left the new Big Ten Network — in a column I wrote last October — the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month — nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network — and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive — ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber — that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.
lead_paragraph: When last we left the new Big Ten Network — in a column I wrote last October — the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month — nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network — and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive — ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber — that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.

headline.main: The Big Ten Wins…Sort Of

abstract: This week’s column recounts an obscure fight involving a company that few people pay attention to anymore, XO Communications. Once a darling of the telecommunications set — just like its competitors Global Crossing and Level 3 — XO fell on hard times, just like, well, Global Crossing and Level 3. After filing for bankruptcy protection in 2003 — a filing that cost Teddy Forstmann’s private equity firm its entire $1.5 billion stake in the company — XO emerged with a new chairman and majority shareholder: none other than Carl Icahn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column recounts an obscure fight involving a company that few people pay attention to anymore, XO Communications. abstract: Sen. Barack Obama may have earned record-breaking ratings for his acceptance speech on Thursday, the final night of the Democratic National Convention, but network television attracted otherwise tiny audiences during prime time. According to Nielsen’s final ratings, CBS led the night with “Big Brother,” which drew 6 million viewers at 8 p.m., the night’s largest audience prior to the 10 p.m. convention coverage. CBS broadcast a rerun of “CSI” at 9 p.m. (5.3 million). Fox ranked runner up on the night with two special episodes of its honesty-testing game show “The Moment of Truth” at 8 p.m. (3.7 million) and 9 p.m. (5.2 million). ABC broadcast reruns of its regular Thursday night shows, “Ugly Betty” (3.1 million) and “Grey’s Anatomy” (4 million), at 8 and 9 p.m., respectively. Meanwhile, NBC struggled in a distant fourth place with pre-season football coverage of the Jacksonville Jaguars’ victory over the Washington Redskins, which averaged 2.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:53 p.m.

headline.main: Ratings: Barack Obama, and All the Rest

abstract: Utah has become the first state to experience broad consumer interest in running cars on clean natural gas.

abstract: Europeans’ confidence fell more than forecast this month as the economy teetered on the brink of a recession.

lead_paragraph: Europeans’ confidence fell more than forecast this month as the economy teetered on the brink of a recession. An index of executive and consumer sentiment dropped to 88.8 from 89.5 in July, the European Commission said. Inflation unexpectedly eased in August and a measure of consumer-price expectations declined.

headline.main: European Index of Economic Confidence Slumps
headline.print_headline: European Index of Economic Confidence Slumps

abstract: The Boeing Company’s largest union urged members to reject a contract offer next week and walk off the job in a strike that would shut production and may further delay the 787 Dreamliner.
snippet: The Boeing Company’s largest union urged members to reject a contract offer next week and walk off the job in a strike that would shut production and may further delay the 787 Dreamliner.
lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company’s largest union urged members to reject a contract offer next week and walk off the job in a strike that would shut production and may further delay the 787 Dreamliner. The union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, also filed unfair-labor practice charges against Boeing “for their direct dealing with our members,” said a union spokeswoman, Connie Kelliher. Boeing put full proposals online during the talks instead of letting union leaders present details to members, drawing the complaint. Boeing said it wanted more open communication with the 27,000 machinists.

headline.main: Union Urges a Strike at Boeing
headline.print_headline: Union Urges a Strike at Boeing

lead_paragraph: I ADMIRE Barack Obama.
